description:
The Human CSF-associated densovirus (HCsADV) is a member of the Densovirinae subfamily within the Parvoviridae family. Densoviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses that primarily infect invertebrates, such as insects and crustaceans.

The HCsADV is a unique densovirus that has been detected in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of some human patients. It is a circular, single-stranded DNA virus with a genome size of approximately 5 kilobases. The viral genome encodes for essential proteins required for viral replication and assembly, including the non-structural (NS) and structural (VP) proteins.

The specific host cell tropism and pathogenicity of HCsADV in humans are not yet fully understood. However, its presence in the CSF suggests a potential association with neurological or central nervous system-related disorders, although further research is needed to elucidate its role, if any, in human disease. Ongoing investigations aim to better characterize the epidemiology, genomic features, and potential clinical implications of this novel human-associated densovirus.
